title: Dominant Kevin Harvick wins AAA 400
text:
Report an error 
Make no mistake, the whole purpose of the Chase for the NASCAR Sprint Cup Championship was to create drama in the final 10 races of the season to keep interest high among fans against the onslaught of the NFL season. 
Well on Sunday NASCAR bosses got that and more in the first elimination race at Dover International Speedway in the AAA 400. 
When the smoke cleared six time champion Jimmie Johnson — a four-time race winner this season in the No. 48 Hendrick Motorsports Chevrolet — was out of the Chase after a rear-end failure on Lap 102 of the 400-lap race. 
And reigning champion Kevin Harvick, who came into to Dover 23 points out of contention to move to the next round, dominated the race on Sunday leading 355 laps and cruising to victory in the No. 4 Stewart Haas Racing Chevrolet. 
In a must-win situation Harvick came through for the third time in the past six Chases races. 
Dale Earnhardt Jr., who looked to be joining Johnson on the sidelines with about 30 laps to go, found extra speed in the No. 88 HMS Chevrolet to pass and eliminate the No. 1 Ganassi Racing Chevrolet of Jamie McMurray. 
Also not advancing are Paul Menard in the No. 27 Richard Childress Racing Chevrolet and Clint Bowyer in the No. 15 Michael Waltrip Racing Toyota. 
The pure irony in Harvick’s improbable victory is that he was put in that must win predicament after tangling with Harvick at Chicagoland Speedway two weeks ago. 
He said he relied on his experience from last season — winning at Phoenix and at Homestead — to do it again on Sunday at Dover. 
“I think we are better than we were last year due to the experience we had to go through,” Harvick said in Victory Lane. 
“Obviously we weren’t in a very good position coming into today but that’s what theses guys (at SHR) are made of; that’s what team work is all about.” 
The pressure to keep winning, however, starts all over again next week at Charlotte Motor Speedway when he second three race Chase segment gets under way. 
Sunday’s race marked Johnson’s 500th career Cup start. 
BAD BREAK 
It seems that Cameron Hayley and the No. 13 Monte Carlo/Carolina Nut Co. Toyota just can’t catch a break this season in the NASCAR Camping World Truck Series. 
Hayley, who qualified sixth for Saturday night’s Rhino Linings 350, moved up the track to take the lead on lap 69 of the 146 lap race at Las Vegas Motor Speedway. 
At one point he had built up a five second lead before a misstep on pit road during a green flag stop put him back to 14th position. 
The 19 year-old Calgary native fought his way back to what looked like a top-five finish when his truck ran low on fuel. 
A stop for a splash of gas ended any chance for a win and resulted in a 10th-place finish. 
It was Hayley’s second fuel issue on a 1.5 mile oval this season. 
“We ran among the leaders the entire race, led some laps, and had a really fast Tundra,” he said in a team release. “I’m not a fan of fuel mileage races but it’s a part of the sport. 
“This is the second fuel mileage race we’ve lost and hopefully our luck can turn around for the rest of the season.” 
BIG SPENDERS 
Mercedes may have won both the Formula 1 constructors’ championship and the world driving championship last season but records released this week show the German auto giant’s racing team lost a whopping $117 million US in 2014. 
Most of the loss, the company said in a statement, came from increased payroll and bonus costs that were a direct result of winning both titles. 
“Operating costs rose by £49.5m ($75 M) due to significantly higher performance bonuses payable as a consequence of the record-breaking level of sporting performance, and also increased costs arising from regulation change,” the report said. 
Mercedes bosses, however, were not concerned about the huge loss saying its was “within the pre-defined parameters set by the shareholders”. 
FINISH LINES 
After tons of speculation that Richard Petty Motorsports might move to Toyota or Chevrolet for engine support in 2016, the team will announce on Tuesday it is staying with Ford for the No. 43 and No. 9 Sprint Cup team according to Motorsport.com. Sponsored Links
